articles.headline: For the Ex-Buccaneer, A Pillage-Free Playlist
articles.snippet: Article compares downloading music illegally from Kazaa with pay services offered by iTunes Music Store from Apple Computer and Rhapsody from RealNetworks; drawing; photos (M)
articles.abstract: Article compares downloading music illegally from Kazaa with pay services offered by iTunes Music Store from Apple Computer and Rhapsody from RealNetworks; drawing; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was time for the Schwartzes to go legit. No more pirated music for us.

articles.headline: Year's Big Rally Helps Investors Regain Ground
articles.snippet: Stocks broke their three-year slide with robust gains in 2003, but market still has far to go to return to heights reached during 1990's; 2003 rally saw Dow Jones average regain 10,000 and had speculative flavor of bubble's peak, as technology sto...
articles.abstract: Stocks broke their three-year slide with robust gains in 2003, but market still has far to go to return to heights reached during 1990's; 2003 rally saw Dow Jones average regain 10,000 and had speculative flavor of bubble's peak, as technology stocks led rebound; year was great relief to investors; Nasdaq composite surged 50 percent to 2003.37, third-best year ever; S&P 500-stock index climbed 26.4 percent to 1,111.92 and Dow climbed 25.3 percent to 10,453.92; Russell 200 index of smaller company stocks had best year, up 45.4 percent to 556.91; big gains in three major market gauges surprised forecasters, who are not predicting 2004 to be as good for stocks; graphs; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks broke their three-year slide with robust gains last year. But the market still has a way to go to return to the heights reached during the bubble that burst in 2000.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth Surges
articles.snippet: India's economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years in the July to September quarter, helped by tax cuts and above-average rains, putting it on course for growth of more than 7 percent in the current fiscal year. The economy expanded 8...
articles.abstract: India's economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years in the July to September quarter, helped by tax cuts and above-average rains, putting it on course for growth of more than 7 percent in the current fiscal year. The economy expanded 8.4 percent from a year earlier, accelerating from 5.7 percent growth in the three months to June 30, the government said.
articles.lead_paragraph: India's economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years in the July to September quarter, helped by tax cuts and above-average rains, putting it on course for growth of more than 7 percent in the current fiscal year. The economy expanded 8.4 percent from a year earlier, accelerating from 5.7 percent growth in the three months to June 30, the government said.

articles.headline: FLIGHT SENT BACK ON TERROR FEAR, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
articles.snippet: American officials have imposed new security measures on incoming flights in past week, reflecting aggressive new approach to guarding US airspace against terrorism; US-bound flight from Mexico was ordered to turn around in midair, stringent secur...
articles.abstract: American officials have imposed new security measures on incoming flights in past week, reflecting aggressive new approach to guarding US airspace against terrorism; US-bound flight from Mexico was ordered to turn around in midair, stringent security measures were imposed on at least six other incoming flights and several Air France flights were canceled at US request; in some cases, planes were ordered to move away from main terminals and passengers were rescreened; officials are also increasing inspection of air cargo on foreign flights; in move that raised hackles abroad, Homeland Security director Tom Ridge has put foreign airlines on notice that they will be denied entry if they refuse to put armed air marshals on any flights of concern (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The American authorities in the last week directed a United States-bound flight from Mexico to turn around in midair and imposed extraordinary security measures on at least six other incoming flights because of terrorist concerns, federal officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cloning Technology Sold
articles.snippet: Scotland's PPL Therapeutics, company that cloned Dolly the sheep, sells rights to its intellectual property, including cloning technology and patents, to Exeter Life Sciences of Phoenix for $1.35 billion; photo (S)
articles.abstract: Scotland's PPL Therapeutics, company that cloned Dolly the sheep, sells rights to its intellectual property, including cloning technology and patents, to Exeter Life Sciences of Phoenix for $1.35 billion; photo (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Scotland's PPL Therapeutics, the company that cloned Dolly the sheep, has sold the rights to its intellectual property, including cloning technology and patents, to Exeter Life Sciences for $1.35 million. Exeter is a Phoenix holding company with subsidiaries that specialize in genetic engineering of plants and animals. PPL is being dismantled after the company's scientific feats were not followed by commercial success.

articles.headline: U.S. Acts to Ban Tax Shelters Using Roth I.R.A.
articles.snippet: Internal Revenue Service and Treasury Dept take steps to ban abusive tax shelter involving use of Roth individual retirement accounts; shelter uses shell corporations to funnel investment contributions into retirement accounts far in excess of cur...
articles.abstract: Internal Revenue Service and Treasury Dept take steps to ban abusive tax shelter involving use of Roth individual retirement accounts; shelter uses shell corporations to funnel investment contributions into retirement accounts far in excess of current limit of $3,500 a year; two agencies declare shelter a 'listed transaction,' meaning that taxpayers, both individuals and companies, must disclose their use of shelter to IRS and that promoters, like accounting firms and lawyers, must keep lists of such taxpayers; such disclosure gives IRS a way of pursuing shelters' users and promoters, both of whom had carried out transactions in secret (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service and the Treasury Department took steps yesterday to ban an abusive tax shelter involving the use of Roth individual retirement accounts.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Jobless Rate Declines
articles.snippet: Unemployment in France declines by 7,000 in November, to 2.26 million, and unemployment rate falls to 9.6 percent from 9.7 percent; national statistics office says France's economy may expand by 2 percent in 2004, fastest rate since 2001 (S)
articles.abstract: Unemployment in France declines by 7,000 in November, to 2.26 million, and unemployment rate falls to 9.6 percent from 9.7 percent; national statistics office says France's economy may expand by 2 percent in 2004, fastest rate since 2001 (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Unemployment in France unexpectedly declined for a second month in November, a sign that prospects for faster growth may be encouraging companies to take on additional workers. The number of job seekers fell by 7,000, to 2.62 million, according to International Labor Organization calculations, said Insee, the national statistics office, which is based in Paris. That cut the unemployment rate to 9.6 percent from 9.7 percent, which had been the highest point in more than three years. Insee predicts that the French economy may expand 2 percent next year, its fastest rate since 2001. ''All the indicators are pointing to a recovery,'' including a pickup in investment and spending, said Jean-Fran√ßois Cope, a government spokesman, in an interview on radio station Europe 1, which is based in Paris.

articles.headline: 7 Detained As Parmalat Investigation Is Widened
articles.snippet: Italian police detain seven executives and advisers of Parmalat and are seeking an eighth, significantly widening investigation of events that led to company's collapse under about $11 billion of liabilities;' are holding two former chief financia...
articles.abstract: Italian police detain seven executives and advisers of Parmalat and are seeking an eighth, significantly widening investigation of events that led to company's collapse under about $11 billion of liabilities;' are holding two former chief financial officers, Fausto Tonna and Luciano del Soldato, as well as company lawyer and two of its auditors from Grant Thornton; photo of Lawrence West, associate director for enforcement at SEC, which is collaborating with Italian authorities investigating troubles at Parmalat (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Italian police detained seven executives and advisers of Parmalat on Wednesday and were seeking an eighth, significantly widening the investigation of events that led to the company's collapse under about $11 billion of liabilities.

articles.headline: $88 Billion in Sales of Emerging-Market Bonds
articles.snippet: Record $88 billion in bonds are sold by emerging-market borrowers in 2003, responding to demand for higher-yielding assets after interest rates in US fell to lowest levels in four decades; companies in developing countries help generate 70 percent...
articles.abstract: Record $88 billion in bonds are sold by emerging-market borrowers in 2003, responding to demand for higher-yielding assets after interest rates in US fell to lowest levels in four decades; companies in developing countries help generate 70 percent increase in debt by selling $44.5 billion of international bonds, surpassing government sales for first time; Latin American companies alone triple sales to $17 billion; surge in sales also reflects raising of credit ratings for Russia and Argentina and prospects for faster global economic growth; premium that emerging-market bonds pay above US Treasuries narrows to 4.22 percentage points from 7.65 percentage points at end of 2002; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Gazprom, the Russian natural gas producer, and Petroleo Brasileiro, a government-owned oil company, led a record $88 billion of bond sales by emerging-market borrowers in 2003, tapping into demand for higher-yielding assets after interest rates in the United States fell to the lowest levels in four decades.

articles.headline: India's Soybean Farmers Join the Global Village
articles.snippet: India's soybean farmers now rely on computers to check futures prices on commodities exchanges, check local prices before going to market and communicate with other farmers worldwide; network, called e-choupal, from Hindi word for village square o...
articles.abstract: India's soybean farmers now rely on computers to check futures prices on commodities exchanges, check local prices before going to market and communicate with other farmers worldwide; network, called e-choupal, from Hindi word for village square or gathering place, was started by ITC Ltd; network has done as much as anything to bridge nation's vast digital divide, and may offer model for all developing countries; through array of satellites that allow it to sidestep shaky power supply and lack of phone lines, ITC has instantly broadened villagers' horizons; idea of e-choupals was to allow company to capture more of soybean market, but it is blooming into vast network providing data that will increase farmers' production and income as well; other ventures, agricultural and beyond, planned by ITC discussed; map; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: At least once a day in this village of 2,500 people, Ravi Sham Choudhry turns on the computer in his front room and logs in to the Web site of the Chicago Board of Trade.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Energy Company Plans To Split Up
articles.snippet: Denison Energy plans to separate its mining and energy operations as part of plan that may also involve acquisition of Calfrac Well Services for 228 million Canadian dollars ($177 million) (S)
articles.abstract: Denison Energy plans to separate its mining and energy operations as part of plan that may also involve acquisition of Calfrac Well Services for 228 million Canadian dollars ($177 million) (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Denison Energy plans to separate its mining and energy operations as part of a plan that may also involve the acquisition of Calfrac Well Services for 228 million Canadian dollars ($177 million). The company, which is based in Toronto, said it planned to transfer all oil and gas assets to Denison Resources, while mining and environmental assets and liabilities will be transferred to Denison Mines. Denison Energy, whose assets after the restructuring would consist mainly of cash and tax pools, has the option to buy Calfrac, a closely held oil and gas services company based in Calgary, for cash or a combination of cash and stock. Shares of Denison Mines and Denison Resources will be distributed to Denison Energy shareholders, the company said. All three companies will be publicly traded.

articles.headline: Democrats' Plan for Early Nominee May Be Costly
articles.snippet: Democrats' plan to produce party unity by quickly nominating strong candidate in series of rapid-fire primaries may be marred by harsh campaign marked more by daily bickering than sweeping themes and compelling ideas; race has become so rough that...
articles.abstract: Democrats' plan to produce party unity by quickly nominating strong candidate in series of rapid-fire primaries may be marred by harsh campaign marked more by daily bickering than sweeping themes and compelling ideas; race has become so rough that Howard Dean, leader in many polls, has asked party chairman Terry McAuliffe to step in and end attacks against him, but plea has only earned him mocking rebukes from opponents; no candidates have succeeded in establishing sweeping election theme or signature proposals; McAuliffe dismisses concerns about tone of race, predicting party will rally around winner; chart shows primary schedule and number of delegates at stake in each race (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: When Democratic Party officials devised their primary calendar for 2004, they produced a rapid-fire voting schedule intended to quickly produce a nominee who could escape the battering that has hobbled so many presidential candidates over the years.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Sells Unit
articles.snippet: HSBC of Britain sells its US factoring business to CIT Group of Livingston, NJ (S)
articles.abstract: HSBC of Britain sells its US factoring business to CIT Group of Livingston, NJ (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: The British financial services company HSBC said it had sold its United States factoring business, which makes short-term commercial loans in exchange for invoices, to the CIT Group of Livingston, N.J. The unit has about $1 billion in loans, with net assets after liabilities worth about $270 billion, the British bank said. HSBC has been revamping to concentrate on higher profit products.

articles.headline: Lenders Seek Debt Deferral For Korean Credit Card Issuer
articles.snippet: Woorie Bank and 15 other largest creditors of LG Card Co, South Korean credit card company, seek written guarantee from other lenders that they will not attempt to force company to repay 21 trillion won ($18 billion) in debt for at least a year; L...
articles.abstract: Woorie Bank and 15 other largest creditors of LG Card Co, South Korean credit card company, seek written guarantee from other lenders that they will not attempt to force company to repay 21 trillion won ($18 billion) in debt for at least a year; LG Card is seeking another 2 trillion won from creditors to keep operating, and South Korea's financial watchdog agency recommends that creditors accept extension, saying that new bailout might not be approved without it; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The 16 main creditors of the LG Card Company, the country's largest credit card company, are seeking a written guarantee from the other lenders that they will not attempt to force the company to repay 21 trillion won ($18 billion) in debt for at least a year, executives at Woori Bank said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telephone Stake Sold
articles.snippet: Singapore Telecommunications sells 92.4 million euros worth of stock in Belgacom, Belgian telephone company, back to company (S)
articles.abstract: Singapore Telecommunications sells 92.4 million euros worth of stock in Belgacom, Belgian telephone company, back to company (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Singapore Telecommunications, one of Southeast Asia's largest phone companies, sold 92.4 million euros ($116 million) worth of stock in Belgacom, the Belgian telephone company, back to the company. Singapore Telecommunications cut its interest in Belgacom to 11.72 percent from 12.15 percent, it said in a statement to the city's stock exchange. The company said it would announce later the net gain from the sale. The sale set off hope among investors that Singapore Telecom would increase its dividend.

articles.headline: Baghdad Bomb Kills at Least 5 At a Restaurant
articles.snippet: Car bomb tears through popular Baghdad restaurant filled with New Year's Eve revelers, killing at leave five people and wounding more than 30, including three Americans; blast is worst of rash of bombings, confirming fears that insurgents would us...
articles.abstract: Car bomb tears through popular Baghdad restaurant filled with New Year's Eve revelers, killing at leave five people and wounding more than 30, including three Americans; blast is worst of rash of bombings, confirming fears that insurgents would use holiday as occasion to mount attacks; rescue efforts described; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: A car bomb tore through a popular restaurant here filled with dozens of New Year's Eve revelers on Wednesday night, killing at least 5 people and wounding more than 30, including 3 Americans.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong

articles.headline: The Very Rich, It Now Appears, Give Their Share And Even More
articles.snippet: New Tithings Group, charity that tracks giving, reports that top 400 American earners in 2000 provided nearly 7 percent of all charitable gifts reported on income tax returns for that year, well in excess of their roughly 1 percent share of overal...
articles.abstract: New Tithings Group, charity that tracks giving, reports that top 400 American earners in 2000 provided nearly 7 percent of all charitable gifts reported on income tax returns for that year, well in excess of their roughly 1 percent share of overall income; 400 taxpayers with highest reported incomes in 2000 made an average of $174 million and gave away, on average, $25.3 million that year; their combined giving totaled $10.1 billion, or 6.9 percent, of $146 billion in charitable donations that Americans deducted on their income tax returns in 2000; photo of Bill and Melinda Gates, among 400 top earners, and top charitable givers (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The top 400 American earners in 2000 provided nearly 7 percent of all the charitable gifts reported on income tax returns for that year, well in excess of their roughly 1 percent share of overall income, according to data released yesterday by the NewTithing Group, a charity that tracks giving.

articles.headline: Calling's Retro Touch
articles.snippet: David Pogue State of the Art column on use of cellular phones as walkie-talkies; Nextel's service is so successful that Verizon and Sprint are now offering walkie-talkie service; photo; drawing (M)
articles.abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on use of cellular phones as walkie-talkies; Nextel's service is so successful that Verizon and Sprint are now offering walkie-talkie service; photo; drawing (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: IT'S weird: even as communications technologies become more advanced, the older, simpler methods sometimes seem to become more attractive. Video chats over the Internet may be free and easy, but the masses stick to the humble telephone. Cellphones can transmit both voice and photos, but millions of people prefer to fire off short, painstakingly typed text messages. What's next, a comeback tour for smoke signals?

articles.headline: Merger Renaissance A Good Possibility In the Coming Year
articles.snippet: Wall Street merger deal-makers predict that merger mania will return in coming year; Thomson Financial reports that deal volume in United States rose to $525 billion in 2003 from $439 billion, attaining a level that compares with 1995; capture of ...
articles.abstract: Wall Street merger deal-makers predict that merger mania will return in coming year; Thomson Financial reports that deal volume in United States rose to $525 billion in 2003 from $439 billion, attaining a level that compares with 1995; capture of Saddam Hussein, beginning of criminal cases against those accused of accounting fraud and steadier stock market may finally provide enough confidence in boardroom and top echelons of management to pursue more deals; table shows some big mergers and acquisitions in 2003 (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The last couple of years have been lousy for the corporate takeover business. The war in Iraq, the accounting scandals and the stock market's resulting instability all worked against the kind of megadeals that reshaped corporate America in the late 1990's.

articles.headline: The Old Block of Ice And a Few New Chips
articles.snippet: Ice carvers are increasingly using computer-driven carving machines to produce intricate sculptures traditionally made by chefs or artisans; John Bayley, founder of Iceculture, developed one of first computer-driven machines; process and equipment...
articles.abstract: Ice carvers are increasingly using computer-driven carving machines to produce intricate sculptures traditionally made by chefs or artisans; John Bayley, founder of Iceculture, developed one of first computer-driven machines; process and equipment described; prices noted; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: AS you read this, some of last year's coolest technology products may have already melted down. Not the iPod or TiVo or the Xbox or the BlackBerry, but holiday decorations fashioned from ice, like Santa Claus, Father Time, snowmen, angels, star bursts, castles and even party masks.

articles.headline: A Continent Divided by Water, Now United by Air
articles.snippet: Success of AirAsia, Malaysia's first low-cost airline, encourages creation of similar ventures elsewhere in Asia, including Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand and Singapore; established airlines are setting up their own low-cost airlines to protect ...
articles.abstract: Success of AirAsia, Malaysia's first low-cost airline, encourages creation of similar ventures elsewhere in Asia, including Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand and Singapore; established airlines are setting up their own low-cost airlines to protect themselves; whether low-cost airlines will flourish in Asia is matter of debate; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years and a few months ago, Anthony F. Fernandes quit his job as one of the most powerful men in Asia's music industry, cashed in his stock options, mortgaged his house and bought a struggling Malaysian airline with two jets and $37 million in debt. Days later, terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center.

articles.headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
articles.snippet: Nasdaq Led Comeback For Stocks in 2003  Stocks broke their three-year slide with robust gains last year. But the market still has a way to go to return to the heights reached during the bubble that burst in 2000. Still, the year was a great relief...
articles.abstract: Nasdaq Led Comeback For Stocks in 2003  Stocks broke their three-year slide with robust gains last year. But the market still has a way to go to return to the heights reached during the bubble that burst in 2000. Still, the year was a great relief to investors who had lived through a recession, an anemic recovery and the worst market decline since the 1970's.    For 2003, the Nasdaq composite index surged 50 percent, to 2,003.37, its third best year ever. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 26.4 percent, to 1,111.92, while the Dow Jones industrial average, which surged 6.9 percent in December, climbed 25.3 percent, to 10,453.92. [Page A1.]
articles.lead_paragraph: Nasdaq Led Comeback For Stocks in 2003

articles.headline: A Time for Finesse: Marketing Beef After a Mad Cow Discovery
articles.snippet: Big players in the meat industry are walking delicate line in their marketing and communications efforts amid consumer concern over mad cow disease; while most food and restaurant companies and ranchers are depending heavily on Agriculture Dept to...
articles.abstract: Big players in the meat industry are walking delicate line in their marketing and communications efforts amid consumer concern over mad cow disease; while most food and restaurant companies and ranchers are depending heavily on Agriculture Dept to reassure public that American beef supply is considered safe so far, some companies are making moves to inform consumers that their individual products have not been tainted; Burger King Corp executives instruct their advertising creative team to retool new ads to include chicken Whopper along with beef Whopper; graph shows near-month contracts for cattle; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Burger King has added something different to its Whopper ads: chicken.
